Hey @mistercrunch  - We treat the existence of a dag_run (marked success) as a persistent record that data has been processed for that day, so it's good for the schedule and as an artifact for record-keeping.

If we can't get it into the CLI (as a flag saying "create a dag_run for this backfill), would you be open to either a collection of utilities that exists outside the CLI for this sort of thing?  I imagine utilities like these would be helpful for quickly re-trying dags with different architectures to help understand good design patterns for airflow. Also, we're going to make mistakes and need to create/re-instantiate dag_runs.
Checking in.

Thank you very much @syvineckruyk! These are great news. We use Ansible too and this is exactly what we have in mind if we didn't develop a functionality to integrate this feature into the CLI, so these scripts are very useful.

In the mid term, would it be nice to integrate it in the CLI and instead of using Ansible variables, using YAML files or something similar? If this is a better way to go in the mid term, I may look into it and provide a PR in the future.

Thanks again for your comment!

I support this -- though there may be reasons for the default connections that I'm not aware of. @mistercrunch will have to weigh in. In any case, I usually delete them all.

@sdiazb there is a setting `airflow.cfg` called `load_example_dags`. You may want to leverage that setting rather than (or in addition to) an explicit CLI call.

@jlowin I hadn't thought about it, but, maybe, having the property in the airflow config file instead of passing as a parameter through the CLI is cleaner. If you prefer this approach, I can easily change it, I think it wouldn't take me more than five minutes. What I wouldn't do is having both options as it could obscure clarity.
Please reopen if issue continues to persist
ok. this has been fixed in master, not in 1.7.1rc2 (@mistercrunch) @r39132 @criccomini

Can you clarify what is happening as I don't think your analysis is correct. The scheduler does not wait on the executor except if the sequentialexecutor is used. However, if you are using SubDags a lot you can run out of executor slots, but what you are describing seems different. 

Please provide a way to replicate the behavior you are observing.

Please have a look at #1391 I'm not too happy with this kind of functionality directly inside the cli. Yes, this deviates from earlier, but the cli is getting hard to maintain and replicates functionality.

Did further testing and although it did fix UI more issues cropped up essentially any DB interactions through pymssql will fail if you do `from builtins import str`. They all fail at this line https://github.com/pymssql/pymssql/blob/master/src/_mssql.pyx#L198 in pymssql which is Cython and expects bytes but airflow provided strings encode to newbytes.

I've hacked it to work by calling `__native__.()` on the return inside pymssql but that's not a viable solution.

If no one has a solution to this can we note this issue and remove the MSSQL compatibility claim from the README?
@bolkedebruin cool, all good points and glad to see the API support!  I'll make changes accordingly once #1391 is merged.
Closing for now.

@lamdrew : I think this could be a useful feature to add. We'd be happy to review a PR for it.
+1 I'm not sure what our test strategy is for testing db hooks/operators for different db backends, but can you look into adding some mock tests in a follow-on PR?
Great endeavor. Can we see a design/operation consideration document for this PR?

👏 As an aside, when using the Branch operator, the second assumption above is not exactly accurate, specifically `For example, if an Operator is marked with 'one_success' this will never get run because it is artificially marked as SKIPPED, even if one of it's other upstream dependencies is successful.` I agree it is a stumbling point and hence welcome the work in this PR. In the above example, I branch at `check_for_time_to_build_model_branch_condition` and join at `wait_for_previous_hour` with a trigger rule of `ONE_SUCCESS`. I needed to insert a dummy operator `prejoin_preagg_dummy_job` to make this work unfortunately, because if I didn't, `wait_for_previous_hour` would always be skipped as mentioned by @withnale.

I found the answer to my question (shown below for my dev machine!): I see this is called by `/refresh` and `/refresh_all` endpoints on the webserver (e.g. [refresh_all](http://localhost:9999/admin/airflow/refresh_all)) Here's the result of executing `refresh_all` in the UI: Here's the result of executing `refresh` by clicking on the cycle icon next to the dag in the UI: Executing these changed the last_expired column value as shown below **Before Refresh**: ``` airflow=# select distinct(last_expired) from dag where is_active=True; last_expired ---------------------------- 2016-04-17 17:33:07.270549 (1 row) ``` **After Refresh**: ``` airflow=# select distinct(last_expired) from dag where is_active=True; last_expired ---------------------------- 2016-04-17 17:38:45.303884 (1 row) ```

Well, I'm using LocalExecutor without many SubDags.

When scheduler runs out of cycles, it calls on executor's end()
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/jobs.py#L788

Which leads to https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/executors/local_executor.py#L75

From https://docs.python.org/2/library/multiprocessing.html#multiprocessing.JoinableQueue
The JoinableQueue used by LocalExecutor will block on join() method until the message are cleared by workers. If any worker process is taking a long-running task, it blocks the call. 

Anyway, that's just my brief investigation of a production issue that we found using LocalExecutor and a long-running sensor task. I'll try to reproduce it locally and past some codes.
Oh sweet, I just realized this was happening! Amazing. This should help speed up or schedule cycles that have been slipping lately from <1minute to 7+ minutes
Nice!

I'm not big on this PR, missed it earlier this week, especially the `sys.path` handling could lead to almost impossible to debug problems. 

I'm not sure why it's necessary. How is a zip file better than a python package?

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/5824014/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/5824014)

Coverage decreased (-0.01%) to 67.033% when pulling **8750d75368a90e28adb2511c59aca984a617ea20 on r39132:master** into **c3f68929a1f8537c2fc8a075ecbfdc760fc45d47 on airbnb:master**.
@mistercrunch Thanks! You might have been hit by #1374 as well, the fix also improved speed quite a lot for @criccomini

@mistercrunch The main reasons for having this in are:
1. In the case of not being able to install packages on the OS, ie. in our environment there is a separation of concerns so we are not allowed to install packages or update them, you can now package your DAGs together with dependencies.
2. Versioning: Although this is a bit in the future, we could allow airflow only to pickup dependencies from site-wide or from a "dag-zip" to allow multiple versions.
3. Combining multiple dags into 1 zip for better manageability.

Where our perspectives might differ is that we are not using "git sync" and we have the need to make the addition of dags authenticated and easier to manage. This is first step towards that.

Adding it to sys.path is standard python and is fully supported, but to address your concerns I could make it configurable by adding a "support_zip_dag" and "support_zip_dependencies" and a a log.info when a dependency is picked up and added to the sys.path. Would that be better?
I don't think it is related to the multiprocessing scheduler changes. Did you try @jlowin 's #1378?

Ah ok. Now I understand the issue and I agree that airflow should behave differently although I don't think airflow should just terminate: you data could be in limbo or the question becomes how to shutdown cleanly?

But the current behavior seems to defeat the purpose of num_runs, but I am not sure maybe @mistercrunch or @r39132 wants to comment on this.
@r39132 Yes and no. I want to have a look at that separately and understand it well, therefore first the partial fix and then I want to address the more core issue in a new PR.
@r39132 I think the file location might be the wrong place. I think this one should go to airflow.contrib, especially as we cannot really test it and oracle is not under APL2.

Yeah, the scheduler behavior is kinda inconsistent between Executors. E.g using CeleryExecutor, it looks like scheduler ends num_runs without holding on to any task execution whereas for LocalExecutor it does. In terms of shutting down tasks, we've designed our operator to be idempotent using XCom so that a random task kill is fine for us. As a workaround, we gave the sensor task a short timeout with many retries so that it doesn't always block scheduler. But it'll be great to know what you think on this issue. Thanks a lot!

Though the implementation seems pretty straight-forward, I'm concerned about a few things : 
1. Operational considerations (e.g. Assuming the LocalAPIClient is default, this concern will be allayed)
2. What is the implication of adding and removing fields to the API version and Protobufs IDL from the Variable. What is your change migration strategy (i.e. adding a field, generating new IDL, changing the API version, etc...)

I'm uncomfortable with this going into master without a design document that touches on the points above.

@jlowin Thanks for the note. "Next scheduled run date" would definitely be useful. Before I implement it, just want to confirm that by DAG UI, do you mean adding an additional field in the table in **Browser -> DagRun**?  Or do you have another place for it in mind?

As for Cluster Monitoring, a separate page will probably be created, i.e. **Admin -> Cluster Monitoring**.
I discussed with @criccomini  about this and would like to get your input on it:

Currently, the pid that the scheduler job is running on is not tracked anywhere in the db, which implies that if the process gets killed for whatever reason while running, the job state in the db will stuck as 'running' forever and can be misleading in the UI. Would it make sense to do a kill_zomebies() for the Jobs similar to how the TIs works (i.e. if it's been a long time since the last heartbeat)?  Or are there any caveats to this?

Another question related to this but is on a higher level is that in general, there are some information we are not currently tracking in the db: if we have 2+ schedulers on the same instance, we cannot differentiate them from one another other than the Job Id, since the ids are assigned arbitrarily. Would it make sense to introduce pid or port or some kind of unique identifier so we know exactly which scheduler is down?
